results.title: Never Done: Women, Work and History
results.brief_description: ‘Never done: women, work and history’. Focuses on women in the workplace from the mid-1800s through to the 1970s including footage of the first women’s union (1882); industrialisation and factory work; the birth of the modern office worker (1890s); equal pay for equal work movement; WWI and WWII women in the workforce; trade-unionism and feminism.

results.title: Close to Slavery: Black Work in White History
results.brief_description: Comprehensively portrayed by the archival footage in this film is a harrowing history of a government policy forcing Aboriginal Australians to assimilate to the white definitions of education and work, mission stations, removal of Aboriginal children, forced labour often in deplorable conditions and exploitation.

results.title: Another day, another dollar: three short films about the history of work
results.brief_description:
“Projected memories: work in old films”: In 1947, a projectionist took a collection of instructional 16mm films about work to the bush. This short film includes excerpts from that collection covering early footage (1900s-1930s) of families on the land; factory workers; steel workers; coal miners; working women; the rise of trade-unions and the 8-hour day; peace campaign of 1938; the invention of the teleprinter; the arrival of the corner grocer shop and much more.
“Never done: women, work and history”: Focuses on women in the workplace from the mid-1800s through to the 1970s including footage of the first women’s union (1882); industrialisation and factory work; the birth of the modern office worker (1890s); equal pay for equal work movement; WWI and WWII women in the workforce; trade-unionism and feminism.
“Close to slavery: black work in white history”: It was government policy for Aboriginal Australians to assimilate to the white ethics of education and work whereas traditional Aborigines did not recognise the western idea of work and preferred to follow their own cultural identity. Then came the mission stations, removal of Aboriginal children, forced labour often in the most deplorable conditions, exploitation and even when black Australians were trained in skilled work through the mission stations, white Australians would not employ them - all this most comprehensively portrayed by the archival footage in this film.

results.title: Hand-coloured film
results.brief_description: It’s estimated that about 80% of films made between the 1890s and the 1920s were coloured through tinting, toning, stencilling and hand-colouring. This process helped bring vibrancy and beauty to fluttering butterfly wings, hypnotic dances and much more.

constellations_primary.name: Colour and creativity
constellations_primary.description: From dying film to Technicolor and beyond, creative applications of colour have been part of cinema since its inception.

results.description: Think the beginning of cinema was all black and white? Think again. Artists have been colouring films since films were invented. It’s estimated that about 80% of films made between the 1890s and the 1920s were coloured through tinting, toning, stencilling and hand-colouring. This work was done from the mid-1890s by colourists like Elisabeth Thuillier. Thuillier employed 200 women in her Paris workshop, where they worked on a production line and each painted one colour on a film. This process helped bring vibrancy and beauty to fluttering butterfly wings, hypnotic dances and much more.
description_for_label: Think the beginning of cinema was all black and white? Think again. Artists have been colouring films since films were invented. It’s estimated that about 80% of films made between the 1890s and the 1920s were coloured through tinting, toning, stencilling and hand-colouring. This work was done from the mid-1890s by colourists like Elisabeth Thuillier. Thuillier employed 200 women in her Paris workshop, where they worked on a production line and each painted one colour on a film. This process helped bring vibrancy and beauty to fluttering butterfly wings, hypnotic dances and much more.

Animated geometry: the angle at the circumference

results.title: Subtended arc
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Animated Geometry”
Two straight lines intersecting at a fixed angle are made to slide on the extremities of a fixed straight line; the point of intersection traces out a complete circle.

results.title: A Circle is determined by three points
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Animated Geometry”.
The three degrees of freedom of a circle - the radius and the co-ordinates of the centre - are reduced stage by stage until finally three points are given. Animated diagrams.
